dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So Amazon Web Services is really pushing back on this whole deposition request, huh? They don't want Vice President Pence or Defense Secretary Esper testifying.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So Amazon Web Services is really pushing back on this whole deposition request, huh? They don't want Vice President Pence or Defense Secretary Esper testifying.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a filing with the U.S. Court of Federal Claims, Amazon Web Services asked a judge to allow depositions from Trump, Esper, former Defense Secretary Jim Mattis and Defense Department Chief Information Officer Dana Deasy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they're also asking for court-ordered discovery, which basically means they don't want the Trump administration handing over emails or documents related to the $10 billion contract.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they're also asking for court-ordered discovery, which basically means they don't want the Trump administration handing over emails or documents related to the ten dollars billion contract.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Amazon is also asking for court-ordered discovery, meaning the company wants the Trump administration to hand over documents and emails relating to the contract.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, because Amazon claims Trump's personal bias against Jeff Bezos—you know, over the Washington Post—is what cost them the deal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, because Amazon claims Trump's personal bias against Jeff Bezos-you know, over the Washington Post-is what cost them the deal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Amazon claims it lost the $10 billion contract because Trump is personally biased against CEO Jeff Bezos for his ownership of the Washington Post, which Trump claims publishes unfair and negative coverage about him.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, and they're pointing to Trump's tweets, even one where he called Bezos a genius, as evidence of his hostility.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, and they're pointing to Trump's tweets, even one where he called Bezos a genius, as evidence of his hostility.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The filing cites Trumps tweets attacking Bezos, including one calling him Jeff Bozo, and a passage from an October 2019 book by Mattiss speechwriter, who wrote that Trump said he wanted to screw Amazon out of the contract, as evidence of the presidents intent and hostility toward Amazon.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild though—this all started after Amazon actually lost the contract to Microsoft back in October.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild though-this all started after Amazon actually lost the contract to Microsoft back in October.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Key background: The drama surrounding the contract started even before Amazon lost.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then IBM and Oracle jumped in, accusing the Pentagon of being biased toward Amazon in the first place.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then I B M and Oracle jumped in, accusing the Pentagon of being biased toward Amazon in the first place.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: IBM and Oracle filed complaints with the Government Accountability Office alleging the Pentagon was biased toward Amazon (both claims were eventually dismissed).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which, honestly, just adds another layer to this whole mess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, honestly, just adds another layer to this whole mess.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then Trump said he wouldn't look into the bidding process, which got some lawmakers excited that things might move faster.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then Trump said he wouldn't look into the bidding process, which got some lawmakers excited that things might move faster.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Responding to those complaints, Trump at one point said he would look into the bidding process, stoking fears from lawmakers that the contract might be delayed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But now Amazon's arguing that Trump used his position as president to interfere with government procurement just to settle a score.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But now Amazon's arguing that Trump used his position as president to interfere with government procurement just to settle a score.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: President Trump has repeatedly demonstrated his willingness to use his position as President and Commander in Chief to interfere with government functionsincluding federal procurementsto advance his personal agenda, an AWS spokesperson said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's such a tangled political and legal battle—hard to see how it ends without a lot more drama.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's such a tangled political and legal battle-hard to see how it ends without a lot more drama.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. I mean, when you've got tweets and book quotes being used as legal evidence, you know it's not your typical contract dispute.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. I mean, when you've got tweets and book quotes being used as legal evidence, you know it's not your typical contract dispute.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The filing cites Trumps tweets attacking Bezos, including one calling him Jeff Bozo, and a passage from an October 2019 book by Mattiss speechwriter, who wrote that Trump said he wanted to screw Amazon out of the contract, as evidence of the presidents intent and hostility toward Amazon.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. This is going to drag on for a while.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. This is going to drag on for a while.

artist_script:
AWS is asking a judge to block depositions from Pence, Esper, and others in that JEDI contract dispute.
HostA: So Amazon Web Services is really pushing back on this whole deposition request, huh? They don’t want Vice President Pence or Defense Secretary Esper testifying.
HostB: Yeah, and they’re also asking for court-ordered discovery, which basically means they don’t want the Trump administration handing over emails or documents related to the $10 billion contract.
HostA: Right, because Amazon claims Trump’s personal bias against Jeff Bezos—you know, over the Washington Post—is what cost them the deal.
HostB: Mhm, and they’re pointing to Trump’s tweets, even one where he called Bezos a genius, as evidence of his hostility.
HostA: It’s wild though—this all started after Amazon actually lost the contract to Microsoft back in October.
HostB: And then IBM and Oracle jumped in, accusing the Pentagon of being biased toward Amazon in the first place.
HostA: Which, honestly, just adds another layer to this whole mess.
HostB: And then Trump said he wouldn’t look into the bidding process, which got some lawmakers excited that things might move faster.
HostA: But now Amazon’s arguing that Trump used his position as president to interfere with government procurement just to settle a score.
HostB: It’s such a tangled political and legal battle—hard to see how it ends without a lot more drama.
HostA: For sure. I mean, when you’ve got tweets and book quotes being used as legal evidence, you know it’s not your typical contract dispute.
HostB: Exactly. This is going to drag on for a while.
